basics.name: Seán Ó Fithcheallaigh
basics.label: PhD Researcher
basics.summary: PhD researcher, focusing on federated learning, with a background in electronic engineering and software development.

work.name: Ulster University
work.summary: Assist the lecture staff in delivering the practical elements of a module; review lab meterial to ensure there are no issues and highligh any as required; review and edit lab work books.

work.name: Sensata
work.summary: Worked to develop the hardware and software used in the next generation of Tyre Pressure Monitor Systems (TPMS), including the development of BLE sensors, as part of multi-million dollar contracts with Mercedes and Ford; developed data capture system used extensively on test vehicles in Europe, America and China, which reduced the time taken for prototype development; used Python to automate in-house test equipment to allow more efficient use of test equipment.
highlights: PCB Design, Algorithm Development, Data collection and analysis, Scrum master

volunteer.organization: 16th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Ambient Intelligence
volunteer.summary: Assisting the conference organisers and delegates as needed (i.e., registering delegates, audio and visual set up, guiding delegates around the venue.
As a session chair or co-chair, we are tasked with introducing MSc students to present their work; ensure students and sessions keep on track and; invite audience questions

courses: Machine Learning, Big Data and Infrastructure, Deep Learning, Statistical Modelling and Data Mining

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: An Embedded Machine Learning Approach to Assist Navigation for People with Visual Impairments
projects.summary: Investigated the development of a system to assist people with sight loss navigate an unknown environment, using machine learning techniques. The system was developed using Arduino Nano microcontrollers.
